posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked:
Hi, We have been using GRIP this season for vision recognition and we have a Pipeline that detects a cone contour and does some processing on it. It is working in our current lighting environment at school, but I am worried that the Pipeline will work with the lighting at the tournament. Please see the attached image and if you are able to, provide feedback on what we can do to make it more adaptable to other lighting environments. Also, what tips do any of you have for tuning the arguments for “Filter Contours” step (like perimeter, height, etc.)? Thank you!

image 1920×1440 135 KB

image 1920×1440 135 KB

image 1920×1440 135 KB

It looks like you’re off to a good start with your GRIP pipeline.

Judging from the photo, I am guessing you have “warm” fluorescent lighting in your practice area. This will likely produce a more “yellow” tinted light than you’ll find in most arenas or gymnasiums. One thing you can experiment with is bringing in different kinds of lights and seeing how your pipeline reacts when the cone is under different kinds of lighting. If possible, test it outside in direct sunlight.

A few tips on your pipeline…

The first block is downscaling your image to 25% of its original size. If you are only using the camera for blob detection, you may get better performance by reducing the camera resolution and avoiding the rescale operation.

You might want to Blur the image before you do contour detection. This can make the blob a bit more uniform by smoothing out minor color variations or imperfections.

After your HSV Threshold step, you may want to consider using the Erode block to remove small details that could confuse the contour generator. (There is also a pair of complementary blocks whose names I forget offhand that can do this.)

All of this depends on how much noise you are getting in your detection output. Less is more, so if you don’t need a processing step in order to get good results, take it out.

Also, GRIP makes it really easy to run test images through yoru pipeline while tuning, so collect as many images of your target as you can (you can find a lot here on CD) and you’ll have more confidence in your algorithm.

posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked: Wow, this is awesome! Thanks for letting us know! I do have a follow-up question, though. How do you run test images through GRIP? I know that we can add a “Source” of some image file but I am unsure how to give it a constant influx of images to process, if that is what you mean.

Yes, I just select different source images manually.

It is also possible to write a simple python script that will load images or video from a folder and run them through your pipeline code. (I have one half-written here somewhere…) It’s not too hard to do, I just never had the excuse to finish it.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
veg:

complementary blocks

After an erode or dilate you typically want to do the other to the same extent to restore the size of the image and again to handle the other speckle (remove black speckles/remove white speckles). Often image processing packages put the two together as open or close .

I’ve found that the lighting conditions in my team’s work area is worse or harder to adjust to than the real arenas. We’ve tended to plan for much worse than actually happens. Last season the high hub did gave problems with bright lights and windows. We had to have a white point cutoff. I doubt that is needed this year. Probably never hurts to add a black point cutoff but we’ve never seen it help.

For the OP, in Windows OP can get a good screen print without having to take a photo. WindowKey+Shift+S opens the app and you can select what to capture. I typically draw the rectangle that I want and the window or full screen work well, too. OP can paste it in the post.

Not sure if OP will be using generated code on the roboRIO or co-processor or the DriverStaion. Or is this how GRIP will be run at competitions in which case beware that the several outputs sent over NetworkTables are not a transaction and you can get the “X” of one frame combined with the “Y” of the next frame which at high movement speeds can be problematic. There are ways around that depending on where the processing is being done and a GRIP developer helped me here on CD for alternatives.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

For the OP, in Windows OP can get a good screen print without having to take a photo. WindowKey+Shift+S opens the app and you can select what to capture.

On mac: Command+Shift+4 or Command+Shift+5.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Of course then we couldn’t “spy” on the interesting stuff going on in the room. Only looks like a map of the USA, though.

posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked: Cool, thanks. This is my first time dealing with Vision stuff so what exactly does a white and black point do? I’ve also looked online and have seen that erosion and dilation are essentially opposites of each other. But what is the true benefit of eroding or dilating the boundaries of the object that the camera is seeing? How can this be used? Thank you once again!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
veg:

smoothing out minor color variations or imperfections

The “preprocessing” is essentially all about “smoothing out minor color variations or imperfections” as @veg mentioned. The aim is to make it possible and easy to find the one true contour and in a robust context and with a minimum of jitter. You are cognizant of this when you posed the question about different lighting conditions.

erode/dilate or open/close smooth out imperfections on the edge and in the “field” of an object by eliminating small “gaps” be them black or white speckles or jaggies.

There are millions of references about image processing. Maybe this one has better examples than what you found: OpenCV morphology

posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked: Got it, thanks. I do not know why I never just looked at the documentation for OpenCV. Thank you both once again; I appreciate it!
